title: Wednesday, 23rd March, 2016

11:07 am

Let me get the whole statement up

PM

In the light of recent press coverage, Sports Direct wishes to clarify that its current expectations for adjusted underlying EBITDA (before share scheme costs) for the full year to the end of April 2016 are at or around the bottom of the range announced on 8 January 2016.

PM

Dear me

11:08 am
Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 370.40, down 8.8 (-2.32%), High: 388.00, Low: 368.50, Volume: 1.76m
PM

365p live

BE

So what can we say here? I guess we can say that there's now clarity on yesterday's profit warning, of sorts.

11:09 am
BE

And the false market that existed among Times readers only existed for 24 hours. Which is nice.

BE

Here's Exane.

BE

Sports Direct have issued a statement in response to yesterday's press coverage, updating its profit expectations for FY16. Management now expect FY16 underlying EBITDA (pre incentive scheme) to be 'at or around' the bottom end of the previously guided range of £380-420m. There is no detail as to the specific drivers of this downgrade, but consequently, we would expect consensus forecasts to fall c.4%, and could raise some caution to outer year forecasts.

This statement follows yesterday's article in The Times, where Mike Ashley was quoted as saying that Sports Direct were 'in trouble' and 'not trading very well'. There is no detail or quantification as to the specific drivers of the downgrade, although yesterday's article flagged the increasing impact of negative publicity on the brand / trading as well as increasing competitive pressure. Mike Ashley was also quoted as saying the business would struggle to deliver profit growth in the medium term, although consensus was already looking for 6% EBITDA and following today's downgrade will leave FY17 EBITDA at a similar level to FY15.

Following yesterday's article, Sports Direct shares fell 10%. In the context of a c.4% downgrade to consensus forecasts today, would leave the shares trading on a 8x cal-16 EV/EBIT (a peak c.30% discount to the sector). This could still represent an interesting entry point, but it will be difficult to convince a sceptical investor base whilst visibility remains low and absent of positive earnings momentum.

Forecasts
On the back of these results, we expect consensus FY16 EBITDA forecasts to fall c.4% to c.£380m and consensus FY16 PBT to fall c.5% to c.£287m (EPS c.35.5p, -5% yoy).

11:09 am
BE

And RBC.

BE

More cautious on recent trading and outlook: we think trading conditions have remained challenging for Sports Direct due to a softer UK clothing and lower end sportswear market, bad publicity relating to its labour practices and weak sales internationally, particularly in Austria. Sports Direct has a more favourable sporting calendar coming up this summer but we expect volumes to remain subdued due to upwards pressure on pricing and as it will take time to restructure the Heatons business acquired in Ireland. As such we now expect an inflection point for profitability in FY18.

Strong dollar a pain in FY17: we think SPD is unhedged below £/USD1.6 and as such will face a significant dollar sourcing headwind in FY17 on own brand product which it buys from Asia in USD (this makes up c.50% of sales). We think that SPD can offset a small proportion due to local supplier costs falling and will gain a small benefit from a continued shift in mix to higher margin own brand product, however we now assume a net gross margin reduction of -170bps in FY17 and -100bps in FY18. This along with weaker trading has caused our high end FY17 underlying EBITDA forecast to fall by 14%.

Valuation undemanding but profit inflection unlikely until FY18. Based on our revised forecasts SPD trades on an undemanding rating of 11x CY17 P/E or 7x lease-adj.EV/EBITDAR, below its historic average of 8x, however we expect profits to fall slightly in FY18 due to sluggish volumes and more gross margin pressure. SPD doesn't pay a dividend and so doesn't have yield support, however it does have strategic stakes in other retailer/brand companies that we estimate are worth close to £500mn. Overall we think SPD needs to reestablish trading momentum driven by online and international to become a more attractive investment proposition.

BE

Sports Direct’s cal. 16E P/E multiple of 10x and lease-adjusted EV/EBITDAR ratios of 7x are c.20-25% below the historical average reflecting recent earnings disappointments and a lower growth outlook.

We use a DCF analysis to arrive at our price target of 425p. We expect SPD to achieve growth in sales of 3% and in operating profit of 2% over the next 10 years, with a rebound in FCF as capital intensity reduces and its inventory overhang clears.

For our DCF we use a WACC of 9% and a terminal growth rate of 2% on account of SPD’s established position in the UK and some international and online potential.

Our price target supports a Sector Perform rating.

11:10 am
BE

Risks to our rating and price target include:

Sports Direct faces execution risk particularly outside the UK and weather, fashion and inventory risk given that 40% of its sales come from apparel. It also runs the risk of not being able to secure enough premium branded product from third party brands in sportswear and in its premium lifestyle business.

Majority shareholder Mike Ashley owns 55% of Sports Direct’s shares, which brings with it all the pros and cons of investing in a company with a dominant shareholder.

On the one hand, Sports Direct has an entrepreneurial culture and a strong and highly incentivized management team. We would expect Mr Ashley to take operational decisions for the long-term benefit of the business.

On the other hand, shareholders have to be prepared for sudden changes in strategic direction occasionally, including strategic stake holdings in related companies.

BE

That last line is my favourite.

BE

"[S]hareholders have to be prepared for sudden changes in strategic direction occasionally, including strategic stake holdings in related companies" ......

11:11 am
BE

Do they!?

BE

I guess they do if they invest in, say, Facebook.

BE

But a shop that sells six-packs of sports socks?

11:12 am

Which takes me back to the old argument about not investing in any company that sells stuff the customer doesn't want, or need, or understand.

11:21 am
BE

Here's Barclays with some new numbers.

BE

William Hill has released a profit warning this morning and the company is guiding to EBITA of £260-280m vs. current Bloomberg Operating Profit of £308m and Barclays £316m: so the mid-point of the revised range is c. 12% lower than consensus. The reason for the downgrade is two-fold and is centred around the Online division rather than Retail: 1) Gross Win margins Year to Date are soft at 6.2% vs. normalised gross win margins of 8% (impacted by a customer-friendly Cheltenham and customer friendly European football results. 2) A acceleration of time-outs and automatic self-exclusions impacting the online division. Finally, WMH confirms it is discussions to partner with OpenBet (software provider) but there is no official transaction yet. Clearly this is a disappointing statement. We would highlight that Cheltenham was well flagged as being bad for bookmakers and we note that William Hill had previously discussed the negative impact of time-outs and self-exclusions at the FY15 results earlier this year.

BE

(@roddy1234: it's more of a lock in, IIRC.)

11:22 am
BE

BE

This is a surprise given other companies have
reported a strong online performance recently (e.g. 888 yesterday, and Paddy
Power Betfair today does not reference any changes with its COO change).
While these factors are somewhat outside William Hill's control, the statement
also mentions that the company has identified a number of strategic priorities
such as poor UK yields, which could suggest more downside to come when the
review is completed.

BE

£10-15m impact from weaker sports results. The company says that gross
win margins for Online are 1.9 percentage points below expectations in the
period at 6.2%, affected by European football results (notwithstanding
favourable UK football results) and also by the worst Cheltenham results in
recent history.
T he company also says that a number of strategic priorities have been
identified following the appointment of a new Interim MD of Online. These
include refocusing the business on maximising UK customer yields (it has been
acquiring lower value customers), improving performance in non-core
markets, and assessing opportunities for cost efficiencies. This sounds like
there could be more weakness to come once the review is completed, given
these issues do not appear to be included in the downgrade.

11:23 am
BE

Readacross for others? We believe most of the issues are company specific,
as 888 issued a very positive update yesterday with its 2015 results, with an
acceleration in growth in the last 6 months. Paddy Power Betfair also gave a
confident outlook statement, with continued strong growth momentum

11:36 am
BE

Mark Brumby has sent over a few desk notes, which I'll share.

BE

Some of them anyway. If you want the full thing, give him some money.

BE

· Trading:

o Re marketing spend, quality hires, capex, product development, exports, debt stability etc. the group is much-improved

· Other:

o Directors bought shares in material amounts in 2014 and 2015

o The pension fund ‘deficit’ could be a surplus. Who in their right minds would fund 40yr pension liabilities using temporarily-low 10yr bond yields? In which case why define the ‘liability’ that way?

o Actions speak louder than words & McCormick seems willing to put its money where its mouth is.

11:37 am
BE

Bid Approach: A Defining Point between Eras?
· The future for an independent Premier has brightened -but independence is no longer a given

· The bid approach marks the defining point between eras

· PFD was a stale cake, a financial basket case – only now, it would appear, it isn’t

· The group is attractive to its competitors & we have some evidence (admittedly the approaches were only ‘indicative’) that the pension ‘deficit’ is not a poison pill

· And the co is cheap. It is trading (including bid spec., debt & pension deficit) at around 1.5x EV. Unilever, for example, is trading at 2.9x.

· Hence if (and it’s a big if) a bidder could reduce costs & open up new markets for PFD products, why wouldn’t it be prepared to pay quite a lot more than the above?

· Here PFD’s geared nature favours equity. Some 2.2x EV, for example, equates to 110p for shareholders

· Shares are trading below the approach & even below 12mth highs. Yet the co is 1) much improved and 2) may be ‘in play’.

BE

Yep. Even post rally the shares are only back to where they were in May.

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 198.42, down 3.23 (-1.60%), High: 201.00, Low: 198.10, Volume: 4.98m
11:46 am
BE

As part of a larger sweep of the groceries sector.

BE

Which I know the ROTR can't get enough on.

BE

Here's the upshot.

11:47 am
BE

We are downgrading our recommendation on Tesco from Hold to Sell with a target price of 167p. We think
Tesco is executing far better in UK stores, with a significantly improved value proposition, and that this is likely to sustain the recent improvement in trading. However, we think the market has become too optimistic about how quickly this might translate into meaningful profit improvement. Tesco trades on a c.6% FY2018E FCF yield on estimates incorporating a healthy UK margin recovery, while Morrisons and Sainsbury’s both trade on c.7% on expectations that assume margins move sideways. Valuing Tesco on a 7% FCF yield, consistent with our valuation for the rest of the sector, determines our target price of 167p, downside of 17%.

BE

Not the wrong margin 1: We appreciate the potential for Tesco’s UK intake
margin to improve as supplier relationships normalise and see further benefit
from range rationalisation and volume growth. However, we think ongoing
structural pressures will make management inclined to continue to reinvest
gross margin gains back into the proposition for some time, at the very least
limiting the visibility of future margin improvement.

BE

Not the wrong margin 2: Moreover, we are not believers in the idea that
Tesco’s relative scale should deliver a material margin advantage versus
competitors. On a truly comparable ex fuel EBITDAR basis, we forecast an FY
2018 margin for Tesco UK of 7.3%, in line with Morrisons’ 7.4%, lower than
Sainsbury’s 8.8%. We would need to forecast an ex fuel EBITDAR margin of
8.2% (2.9% inc fuel EBIT), 190bp higher than our H216 estimate, in order to
raise Tesco’s FCF yield to 7%. While this is not an impossible prospect, we
think visibility on this extent of progress is very limited.

11:48 am
BE

And in terms of the sector .....

BE

[W]e observe that the main drivers to date of improved LfL growth for the Big 3
quoted grocers have been reduced net new space growth and Asda’s market
share losses, neither of which are likely to be continued sources of growth.
Also, far from being optimistic about the potential return of inflation to UK
grocery, we think there is a very real risk of it driving renewed gross margin
pressure as retailers seek to gain volume by not passing through higher input
costs. Even if some inflation does creep through, we think volume growth will
likely fall to offset this benefit. Tesco also has the most to lose if, as we expect,
Amazon puts online grocery profitability under pressure.

BE

MRW and Sainsbury both hold.

11:48 am

Just to note Game Digital

12:00 pm

12:01 pm
BE

And the biggest shareholder needs to front up cash to avoid the whole thing unravelling.

BE

That's not 2012, amazingly. That's this morning.

BE

Here's Canaccord with the detail.

12:02 pm
BE

GAME Digital reported H1 results ahead of our forecasts reflecting a stronger than
expected end to its key Q2 trading period. Revenues fell 6.3% to £549.2m (CG
£546.1m), driving Ebitda of £33.1m, against our £29.8m forecast and guidance of
"around £30m". PBT (norm) came in at £27.7m/12.2p, vs our £24.0m/11.3p. The
dividend was cut to 1.67p, pointing to a full year pay-out of at least 5.0p, compared with
our 7.35p forecast. Period end net cash was strong at £120.2m, with improved free cash
flow YoY, but management is keen to revert to a progressive dividend payout that does
not restrict growth capital.
Outperformance was a factor of higher gross margin due to mix. Importantly, if we strip
out hardware (low margin and declining), group revenues were up 0.9% YoY (or up 3.1%
on a constant currency basis). And gross profits in the growth categories of Next Gen
software, digital, pre-owned and accessories was up by 25% and accounted for 70% of
the total. The Group continued to gain market share in both Spain and the UK, with Spain
performing particularly strongly. However, the UK market was weak, down 5.2% in the
period, even stripping out hardware; on the same basis, GAME UK revenues were -0.2%.

BE

Management talks about second half trading being "in line with expectations" and it still
expects a modest Ebitda profit in H2. However, following the decision by "certain credit
insurers" to reduce insurance cover, it has entered discussions with some financing
providers, including its major shareholder Elliott, to provide an asset-backed lending
facility of up to £100m. The group is cash generative, and its funding requirements
extremely short-term (the maximum incremental cost of such a facility would be c.£1m),
but this does create some short-term uncertainty.
We are nudging up our FY16F Ebitda from £33.0m to £34.0m although EPS is broadly
unchanged at 10.1p. For FY17F, Ebitda is unchanged at £36.2m, but EPS nudges down
3% on higher interest costs/tax.

BE

GAME shares have performed strongly recently, up 30% since the January 13th trading
update, boosted also by the valuation implications of the Darty bid approach. It now
trades on a calendarised 2016F PER of 12.1x, EV/Ebitda of 5.2x and yields 4.0%,
falling to 11.3x/4.2x in 2017F. The group offers a number of growth drivers (eSports,
digital sales, Gametronics), but remains highly dependent on Xmas trading, and there
will be some disappointment at the extent of the dividend cut. We raise our TP from
115p to 126p to reflect the higher peer group valuations (putting it on a 12.0x FY16F
calendarised PER, 5.0x EV/Ebitda), but move our recommendation from Buy to HOLD.

12:03 pm
BE

Those who don't learn from the past are doomed to buy Game Digital shares.
